pageProps.contentHtml:
construction, harmonic functions

Let Ω\OmegaΩ be the following subset of the complex plane:

Ω={x+iy∣x>0, y>0, and xy<1}.\Omega = \set{x + iy \mid x > 0,\ y > 0,\ \text{and } xy < 1}.Ω={x+iy∣x>0, y>0, and xy<1}.

Give an example of an unbounded harmonic function on Ω\OmegaΩ that extends continuously to ∂Ω\partial\Omega∂Ω and vanishes there.
Solution.

Notice that (x+iy)2=(x2−y2)+2xyi\p{x + iy}^2 = \p{x^2 - y^2} + 2xyi(x+iy)2=(x2−y2)+2xyi. Thus, for z∈Ωz \in \Omegaz∈Ω, we see that 0≤Im⁡z<20 \leq \Im{z} < 20≤Imz<2 and Re⁡z∈R\Re{z} \in \RRez∈R. Conversely, given a+iba + iba+ib such that 0≤b<20 \leq b < 20≤b<2, we can try to solve z2=a+ibz^2 = a + ibz2=a+ib, which means

{x2−y2=a,2xy=b.\begin{cases} x^2 - y^2 &= a, \\ 2xy &= b. \end{cases}{x2−y22xy​=a,=b.​

By inspection, we see that

x=y2bandy∈{−2ba1−4b2,2ba1−4b2}.x = \frac{y}{2b} \quad\text{and}\quad y \in \set{-\frac{2b\sqrt{a}}{\sqrt{1 - 4b^2}}, \frac{2b\sqrt{a}}{\sqrt{1 - 4b^2}}}.x=2by​andy∈{−1−4b2​2ba​​,1−4b2​2ba​​}.

Since b≥0b \geq 0b≥0, we see that xxx and yyy satisfying the above will have the same sign. Since b<2b < 2b<2, the second equation implies xy<1xy < 1xy<1, so z2=a+ibz^2 = a + ibz2=a+ib has a unique solution in Ω\OmegaΩ for any a+iba + iba+ib in the strip S={0≤Im⁡z<2}S = \set{0 \leq \Im{z} < 2}S={0≤Imz<2}. Thus, the map φ ⁣:Ω→S\func{\phi}{\Omega}{S}φ:Ω→S, z↦z2z \mapsto z^2z↦z2 is a conformal map.

Notice that φ\phiφ extends continuously to the boundary. Moreover, if x=0x = 0x=0, then φ(x+iy)=−y2\phi\p{x + iy} = -y^2φ(x+iy)=−y2 and if y=0y = 0y=0, then φ(x)=x2\phi\p{x} = x^2φ(x)=x2. In either case, φ\phiφ maps the the axes to the real line. Also, if xy=1xy = 1xy=1, then φ(x+iy)=x2−y2+2i\phi\p{x + iy} = x^2 - y^2 + 2iφ(x+iy)=x2−y2+2i, so the curve xy=1xy = 1xy=1 in the upper-half plane is mapped into the line y=2iy = 2iy=2i.

In light of φ\phiφ, it suffices to find an unbounded harmonic function which vanishes on y=0y = 0y=0 and y=2iy = 2iy=2i. One such choice is v(z)=Im⁡eπzv\p{z} = \Im{e^{\pi z}}v(z)=Imeπz, since eπze^{\pi z}eπz is purely real on these lines. It is also unbounded, since v(x+i4)=eπxsin⁡π4→x→∞∞v\p{x + \frac{i}{4}} = e^{\pi x}\sin\frac{\pi}{4} \xrightarrow{x\to\infty} \inftyv(x+4i​)=eπxsin4π​x→∞​∞. Thus,

u(z)=v(φ(z))=Im⁡eπz2u\p{z} = v\p{\phi\p{z}} = \Im{e^{\pi z^2}}u(z)=v(φ(z))=Imeπz2

works.
